history.content:
Why does CS research need labs, other than offices? There's nothing physical involved (other than computers).

cf how there are no math labs, or history labs.
Why does CS research need labs, other than offices? There's nothing physical involved (other than computers).

children.subject: [Unconfirmed] I've heard under Jacobs or Sutardja Dai or one of those buildings there is a mini fab (for fabrication of silicon chips), but being right next to fault lines makes it pretty limited.
To the other anon: the Berkeley nanolab is in Sutardja floors 3-5. Fabrication is far from limited; hundreds of people use the facility for research needs 24/7 pretty much every day of the year.
There's labs in the basement of Cory and on the 5th floor too

history.content:
The RISC IS was created walking distance from your apartment. Same with UNIX, TCP/IP and Hadoop. Berkeley is, undisputably, the greatest research university in the world.

My question is, where does all this research happen? Is it in Soda or Cory Hall? I've been to all the floors of both buildings, but I only see offices and classrooms: No labs. The few labs I've seen are small: They don't seem like the homes of the world's greatest CS thinkers. The CS Gods, like Prof. Sahai (control theory), Prof. Shewchuck (computational geometry), Prof. Patterson (computer architecture), who have created the fields they research in.

Are there special buildings for CS research? I know we have the Lawrence National Lab, but that's not for CS.
history.subject: Where does the RESEARCH happen?
